translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
With Sabhiya
Thus have I heard:

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe
translated: At one time the Fortunate One was dwelling amongst the Magadhans at Nādika on the banks of the Ganges.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sabhiyassa paribbājakassa purāṇasālohitāya devatāya pañhā uddiṭṭhā honti:
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sabhiyassa paribbājakassa purāṇasālohitāya devatāya pañhāḥ uddiṭṭhāḥ honti
translated: Then at that time for the wanderer Sabhiya questions had been recited by an old and long-standing deity:

original: “yo te, sabhiya, samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ime pañhe puṭṭho byākaroti tassa santike brahmacariyaṁ careyyāsī”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ te sabhiya samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā ime pañhe puṭṭhaḥ byākaroti tassa santike brahmacariyam careyyāsi iti
translated: “You should live the spiritual life in the presence of that monastic or brahmin who, when asked these questions, answers them.”

original: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako tassā devatāya santike te pañhe uggahetvā ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā
analyzed: atha kho sabhiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ tassāḥ devatāya santike te pañhe uggahetvā ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā
translated: Then the wanderer Sabhiya, after learning these questions from that deity, approached those monastics and brahmins

original: saṅghino gaṇino gaṇācariyā ñātā yasassino titthakarā sādhusammatā bahujanassa, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: saṅghinaḥ gaṇinaḥ gaṇa ācariyāḥ ñātāḥ yasassinaḥ titthakarāḥ sādhu sammatāḥ bahu janassa
translated: who were heads of hermitages, leaders of schools, teachers of schools, well-known and famous as founders of schools, who were regarded by many as being perfected ones, that is to say:

original: pūraṇo kassapo makkhaligosālo ajito kesakambalo pakudho kaccāno sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto—
analyzed: pūraṇaḥ kassapaḥ makkhali gosālaḥ ajitaḥ kesakambalo pakudhaḥ kaccāno sañcayaḥ belaṭṭhaputto nigaṇṭhaḥ nāṭaputto
translated: Pūraṇa Kassapa, Makkhali Gosāla, Ajita Kesakambala, Pakudha Kaccāyana, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta, and Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta—
and asked them about these questions.

original: Te sabhiyena paribbājakena pañhe puṭṭhā na sampāyanti;
analyzed: te sabhiyena paribbājakena pañhe puṭṭhāḥ na sampāyanti
translated: When asked these questions by the wanderer Sabhiya they were unable to give an answer,

original: asampāyantā kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaronti.🔽Api ca sabhiyaṁyeva paribbājakaṁ paṭipucchanti.
analyzed: a sampāyantā kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaronti  api ca sa bhiyayā iva paribbājakam paṭipucchanti
translated: and when they didn’t, they became angry, hostile, and resentful.🔽And they asked me about it.

analyzed: atha kho sabhiyassa paribbājakassa etat ahosi
translated: Then it occurred to me:

original: “ye kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saṅghino gaṇino gaṇācariyā ñātā yasassino titthakarā sādhusammatā bahujanassa, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: ye kho te bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā saṅghinaḥ gaṇinaḥ gaṇa ācariyā ñātā yasassinaḥ titthakarā sādhu sammatā bahu janassa
translated: “There are those venerables, ascetics and brahmins, leaders of groups, leaders of groups of followers, teachers of groups, well-known and famous as founders of schools, who are regarded by many as being holy men—

analyzed: pūraṇaḥ kassapaḥ pe nigaṇṭhaḥ nāṭa putto
translated: Pūraṇa Kassapa …

original: te mayā pañhe puṭṭhā na sampāyanti,
analyzed: te mayā pañhe puṭṭhāḥ na sampāyanti
translated: When I asked them about this, they didn’t answer me.

analyzed: a sampāyantā kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaronti
translated: And when they didn’t, they became angry, hostile, and resentful.

analyzed: api ca maññā iva itthā paṭipucchanti
translated: And they asked me about it.

analyzed: yat nūna aham hīnāya avattitvā kāme paribhuñjeyyanti
translated: Why don’t I return to the lower life and enjoy sensual pleasures?”

analyzed: atha kho sabhiyassa paribbājakassa etat ahosi
translated: Then it occurred to me:

original: “ayampi kho samaṇo gotamo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa;
analyzed: ayam pi kho samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ saṅghī ca iva gaṇī ca gaṇa ācariyo ca ñātaḥ yasassī titthakaro sādhu sammataḥ bahu janassa
translated: “This ascetic Gotama is the leader of an order and a group, and a teacher who is the son of the same parents as his pupils.

original: yannūnāhaṁ samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ upasaṅkamitvā ime pañhe puccheyyan”ti.🔽Atha kho sabhiyassa paribbājakassa etadahosi:
analyzed: yat nūna aham samaṇam gotamam upasaṅkamitvā ime pañhe puccheyyanti  atha kho sabhiyassa paribbājakassa etat ahosi
translated: Why don’t I go to the Buddha and ask him about this?”

original: “yepi kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā jiṇṇā vuḍḍhā mahallakā addhagatā vayoanuppattā🔽therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghino gaṇino gaṇācariyā ñātā yasassino titthakarā
analyzed: ye api kho te bhontaḥ samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ jiṇṇāḥ vuḍḍhāḥ mahallakāḥ addha gatāḥ vayaḥ anuppattā  therā rattaññū cira pabbajitā saṅghinaḥ gaṇinaḥ gaṇa ācariyā ñātāḥ yasassinaḥ titthakarā
translated: The thought occurred to him, “Those who are old, elderly, and senior,
who are the most venerable and well-known teachers of other sects—

analyzed: pūraṇaḥ kassapaḥ pe nigaṇṭhaḥ nāṭa putto
translated: Pūraṇa Kassapa …

original: tepi mayā pañhe puṭṭhā na sampāyanti,
analyzed: te api mayā pañhe puṭṭhāḥ na sampāyanti
translated: even they, when asked these questions, didn’t respond.

original: asampāyantā kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaronti, api ca maññevettha paṭipucchanti;
analyzed: a sampāyantā kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaronti api ca maññā iva itthā paṭipucchanti
translated: Not responding, they displayed anger, revenge, and exasperation. They even asked me questions in return.

original: kiṁ pana me samaṇo gotamo ime pañhe puṭṭho byākarissati.
analyzed: kim pana me samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ ime pañhe puṭṭhaḥ byākarissati
translated: So how will the Buddha respond when I ask him these questions?

original: Samaṇo hi gotamo daharo ceva jātiyā, navo ca pabbajjāyā”ti.🔽Atha kho sabhiyassa paribbājakassa etadahosi:
analyzed: samaṇaḥ hi gotamaḥ daharaḥ ca iva jātiyā navaḥ ca pabbajjāya ati  atha kho sabhiyassa paribbājakassa etat ahosi
translated: After all, the Buddha is young and newly gone forth.”

original: “samaṇo kho daharoti na uññātabbo na paribhotabbo.
analyzed: samaṇo kho daharo ti na uññātabbaḥ na paribhotabbaḥ
translated: The thought occurred to him, “A monk is not to be disrespected or disparaged.

original: Daharopi cesa samaṇo gotamo mahiddhiko hoti mahānubhāvo, yannūnāhaṁ samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ upasaṅkamitvā ime pañhe puccheyyan”ti.
analyzed: daharaḥ api ca isa samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ mahiddhikaḥ hoti mahā anubhāvaḥ yat nūna aham samaṇam gotamam upasaṅkamitvā ime pañhe puccheyyanti
translated: He’s young, but he’s powerful and mighty. Why don’t I go to him and ask him about these matters?”

original: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako yena rājagahaṁ tena cārikaṁ pakkāmi.🔽Anupubbena cārikaṁ caramāno yena rājagahaṁ veḷuvanaṁ kalandakanivāpo, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.🔽Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: atha kho sabhiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ yena rājagaham tena cārikam pakkāmi  anupubbena cārikam caramānaḥ yena rājagaham veḷuvanam kalandakanivāpaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim sammodi  sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: Then the wanderer Sabhiya set out wandering toward Rājagaha.🔽Wandering by stages, he eventually arrived at Rājagaha, at the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary, and went up to the Buddha. He exchanged greetings with the Buddha, and when this courteous and amiable talk was finished, he sat down to one side

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho sabhiyo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi—
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho sabhiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam gāthāya ajjhabhāsi
translated: and addressed the Buddha in verse:
“I’m doubtful and uncertain,
(so says Sabhiya)🔽and I wish to ask a question.
Please answer my questions,
one by one, in line with the Teaching.”
“You’ve come from far away, Sabhiya,
(so says the Buddha)
and you wish to ask a question.
I will answer your questions,
I will explain them in sequence, in accordance with the Teaching.
Ask me, Sabhiya, whatever you want,
Whatever you wish to ask.
I will answer your question,
I will resolve it for you.”

analyzed: atha kho sabhiyassa paribbājakassa etat ahosi
translated: Then this occurred to the wanderer Sabhiya:

analyzed: acchariyam vata bho abbhutam vata bho
translated: “It’s truly wonderful, it’s truly marvellous,

original: Yaṁ vatāhaṁ aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu okāsakammamattampi nālatthaṁ taṁ me idaṁ samaṇena gotamena okāsakammaṁ katan”ti.
analyzed: yam vata aham aññesu samaṇa brāhmaṇesu okāsa kamma mattam pi na alattham tam me idam samaṇena gotamena okāsa kammam katanti
translated: that I have received an opportunity to ask a question from the ascetic Gotama.”

original: Attamano pamudito udaggo pītisomanassajāto bhagavantaṁ pañhaṁ apucchi—
analyzed: atta manaḥ pamuditaḥ udaggaḥ pīti somanassa jātaḥ bhagavantam pañham apucchi
translated: and he was uplifted, and glad, and elated, and joyful, and happy, and he asked the Fortunate One a question:
“What is a monk called, Fortunate One?

analyzed: iti  soratam kena kathañca dantam āhu
translated: (said Sabhiya)🔽What is a good listener called? What is a controlled one called?
How is one called a Buddha?
Please explain this to me, Fortunate One.”
“One who has made himself pliable,

analyzed: sabhiyāti bhagavān  parinibbāna gataḥ vitiṇṇa kaṅkhaḥ
translated: (said the Fortunate One to Sabhiya)🔽Who has gone beyond doubt, who has crossed over uncertainty,
Who has given up both existence and non-existence,
He has lived the spiritual life, and his rebirths have come to an end.
He is impartial and mindful everywhere.
He does not harm anyone in the world.
He is a sage who has crossed over, free of defilements,

original: Ussadā yassa na santi sorato so.
analyzed: ussadāḥ yassa na santi so rataḥ so
translated: Without arrogance, he is at ease.

analyzed: yaḥ indriyāni bhāvitāni  ajjhattam bahiddhā ca sabba loke
translated: His faculties, developed,🔽Are inwardly and outwardly under control.
He has gone beyond this world and the next.
He is a tamed one, developed, who awaits his time.

analyzed: kappāni viceyya kevalāni  sa sāram dubhayam
translated: Having examined all the views,🔽The world’s repeated deceits, birth and death,
He is free of dust and defilements, pure.

analyzed: pattam jāti khayam tam āhu buddha nti
translated: He has attained the end of births. He is called a Buddha.”

original: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā attamano pamudito udaggo pītisomanassajāto bhagavantaṁ uttariṁ pañhaṁ apucchi—
analyzed: atha kho sabhiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinanditvā anumoditvā atta manaḥ pamuditaḥ udaggaḥ pīti somanassa jātaḥ bhagavantam uttarim pañham apucchi
translated: Then the wanderer Sabhiya, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, was satisfied and delighted in what he said. He asked the Buddha a further question:
“What is a brahmin called?
(So said Sabhiya.)🔽How is one a sage? And how is one a monastic?
How is one called a brahmin?
Please explain this to me, O Buddha.”
“Having expelled all bad things,
(the Blessed One said)
The stainless one, the good one, the one who is concentrated, the one who is steady,🔽The one who is complete after passing beyond saṃsāra,

analyzed: asitaḥ ta ādi pavuccate sa brahmā
translated: The one who is not agitated is said to be a brahmā.
The one who has abandoned merit and bad things,
The one who is without dust, the one who knows this world and the next world,
The one who has gone beyond birth and death,
The one who is like that is said to be a monk.
The one who has bathed in all bad things,
In the world, both internally and externally,

analyzed: deva manussesu kappiyesu  kappam neti tam āhu nhātakā iti
translated: Among gods and men, the suitable,🔽The one who goes for a long time, they call him a bather.
The one who does not do anything bad in the world,
The one who has given up all bonds and fetters,
The one who is not attached anywhere, the one who is free,
The one who is like that is said to be a nāga.”

original: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako …pe… bhagavantaṁ uttariṁ pañhaṁ apucchi—
analyzed: atha kho sabhiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ pe bhagavantam uttarim pañham apucchi
translated: Then the wanderer Sabhiya … asked the Blessed One a further question:
“What is the field-conqueror that the Buddhas declare,
(said Sabhiya)
By what is one skilled and wise?
How is one called a sage?
Please explain this to me, Blessed One.”
“Having examined the fields, the only ones,
(The Fortunate One said to Sabhiya)
The divine, human, and Brahmā fields;
Freed from the root-bondage of all fields,
The Victorious One in the fields is called such because of that.
Having examined the treasuries, the only ones,
The divine, human, and Brahmā treasuries;
Freed from the root-bondage of all treasuries,
The one skilled in the treasuries is called such because of that.
Having examined the white and black,
The wisdom of purity, both internally and externally;
Having gone beyond the dark and the bright,
The wise one is called such because of that.
Having known the good and bad Dhamma,
Both internally and externally, in all the world;
Worthy of worship by gods and men,

analyzed: saṅgam jāla matit ca saḥ muni iti
translated: The Sage has escaped the net of attachment.”

original: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako …pe… bhagavantaṁ uttariṁ pañhaṁ apucchi—
analyzed: atha kho sabhiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ pe bhagavantam uttarim pañham apucchi
translated: Then the wanderer Sabhiya … asked the Fortunate One a further question:
“What is the one who has attained called, the one who has knowledge?
(So said Sabhiya)🔽By whom is it known, and how does he cross over with energy?
What is the one who has learned called,
Please explain this to me.”
“Having analyzed the Vedas in their entirety,

analyzed: sabhiyāti bhagavān  samaṇānam brāhmaṇāna  sabba vedanāsu vīta rāgaḥ
translated: (the Blessed One said:)🔽“The ascetic’s and the brahmin’s views🔽are all about feeling.🔽Free from passion for all feelings,
he has transcended all feelings.
Having analyzed name-and-form,
the root of the disease, internally and externally,
he is free from the bondage of the root of the disease.
He is called ‘one who has analyzed’ because of that.

analyzed: virataḥ idha sabba pāpakehi  niraya dukkham aticca viriya vāso
translated: He is free from all evil here,🔽having transcended the suffering of hell.
He is energetic, striving,
he is called ‘one who is energetic’ because of that.
He has cut the bonds
the root of attachment, internally and externally.
He is free from the bondage of the root of attachment.
He is called ‘one who has cut the bonds’ because of that.”

original: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako …pe… bhagavantaṁ uttariṁ pañhaṁ apucchi—
analyzed: atha kho sabhiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ pe bhagavantam uttarim pañham apucchi
translated: Then the wanderer Sabhiya … asked the Blessed One a further question:
“What is called ‘the wise one’?
(So said Sabhiya)
What is the noble one? And how does one go beyond?”
What is a wanderer?

original: Puṭṭho me bhagavā byākarohi”.🔽“Sutvā sabbadhammaṁ abhiññāya loke,
analyzed: puṭṭhaḥ me bhagavā byākarohi  sutvā sabba dhammam abhiññāya loke
translated: Please explain this to me, Fortunate One.”
(The Fortunate One said:) “Having heard all the teachings in the world, and having understood them,

analyzed: sāvat ja anavajjam yat atthi kiñci
translated: (The Fortunate One said:) “Having seen the blameworthy and the blameless, whatever there is,

analyzed: abhibhum akathaṅkathim  anigham sabbadhim āhu sottiyā iti
translated: The one who has overcome, the one who is not a doubter, the one who is liberated,🔽The one who is free from the flood, the one who is free from the bond, they call him a wanderer.”
Having cut off the pollutants, the attachments,
The wise one does not return to the womb,
Having given up the three kinds of perceptions, the mire,

analyzed: kappam na iti tam āhu ariyaḥ iti
translated: They say he goes to the end of the world, the Noble One.”
The one who has attained the practice here,
The skilled one always understands the teaching;
Everywhere he is not attached, with a liberated mind,

original: Paṭighā yassa na santi caraṇavā so.
analyzed: paṭighāḥ yassa na santi caraṇavā so
translated: The one who has no resistance, he is a wanderer.”
Whatever deed has a painful result,

analyzed: uddham adhas tiriyam vā api majjhe
translated: Above, below, across, or in the middle;
Having wandered forth, the one who practices with full understanding,
Having destroyed Māra, conceit, and pride, greed and anger,
Having made an end to mind and body,
They call him a wanderer who has attained the practice.”

original: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā attamano🔽pamudito udaggo pītisomanassajāto uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṁsaṁ uttarāsaṅgaṁ karitvā yena bhagavā
analyzed: atha kho sabhiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinanditvā anumoditvā atta manaḥ  pamuditaḥ udaggaḥ pīti somanassa jāto uṭṭhāya āsanā ekasam uttarāsaṅgam karitvā yena bhagavā
translated: Then the wanderer Sabhiya, having delighted and rejoiced in the Blessed One’s words,🔽rising from his seat, having arranged his upper robe on one shoulder,🔽extended his hands in reverential salutation towards the Blessed One and,🔽having delighted and rejoiced in the Blessed One’s words,

original: tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṁ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
analyzed: tena añjalim paṇāmetvā bhagavantam sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi
translated: he praised him in the Tathagata’s presence with these appropriate verses:

analyzed: yāni ca tīṇi yāni ca saṭṭhi
translated: “The three and the sixty,
the many-wise one, defiled by the ascetic’s censure,
dependent on the perception of the elements and the perception of the self,
having abandoned the floods, the bonds, and the corruptions,

original: Antagūsi pāragū dukkhassa,🔽Arahāsi sammāsambuddho khīṇāsavaṁ taṁ maññe;
analyzed: antagū asi pāragū dukkhassa  arahā asi sammāsambuddhaḥ khīṇa āsavam tam maññe
translated: you have gone to the end of the world, you have gone beyond, you have overcome suffering,🔽you are a Worthy One, a Fully Enlightened One, I think you are one whose corruptions are destroyed;
you are radiant, you are glorious, you are rich in wisdom,
you have put an end to suffering, you have comforted me.
Whatever I had doubts about,
you have saved me from my uncertainty, homage to you;
you are a sage who has attained the path of the sages,
you are unfettered, you are a kinsman of the sun, you are gentle.
Whatever doubt I had before,
the one with vision has explained it to me;
surely you are a sage who is fully enlightened,
there are no hindrances for you.

analyzed: upāyāsā ca te sabbe  viddhastā vinaḍīkatā
translated: All your troubles🔽are known and destroyed.
You are cooled and attained self-control,

analyzed: dh timā sacca nikkamaḥ  tassa te nāga nāgassa
translated: mindful and with right release.🔽When the great hero, the dragon of dragons,
the Buddha, spoke this verse,
all the gods rejoiced,
both Nārada and Pabbata.
Homage to you, O human noble,
homage to you, O supreme human;
in the world with its gods
there is no one equal to you.
You are the Buddha, you are the teacher,
you are the sage who has overcome Māra.

analyzed: tuvam anusaye chetvā  tiṇṇaḥ tāresimam paja
translated: Having cut the fetters,🔽you have crossed over, and you liberate this people.
You have gone beyond the attachments,
and your effluents are destroyed.
You are a lion, free from clinging,
having given up fear and dread.
Just as a beautiful lotus

original: Toye na upalimpati;🔽Evaṁ puññe ca pāpe ca,
analyzed: toye na upalimpati  evam puññe ca pāpe ca
translated: is not soiled by the water,
so you are not soiled🔽by either merit or evil.
Hero, stretch out your feet,
Sabhiya pays homage to the Teacher.”

original: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho sabhiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ bhagavataḥ pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then the wanderer Sabhiya, having bowed his head at the feet of the Blessed One, said to him:

“Magnificent, Master Gotama! Magnificent!🔽Just as if he were to place upright what was overturned,🔽to reveal what was hidden,🔽to show the way to one who was lost,🔽or to carry a lamp into the dark so that those with eyes could see forms,

original: esāhaṁ bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca;
analyzed: esā aham bhagavantam saraṇam gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhu saṅghañca
translated: I go for refuge to the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha of monks.

original: labheyyāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyaṁ upasampadan”ti.
analyzed: labheyya āha bhante bhagavato santike pabbajja labheyyam upasampadanti
translated: Venerable Sir, may I receive the going forth in the Buddha’s presence, may I receive the full ordination?”

original: “Yo kho, sabhiya, aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṁ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajjaṁ, ākaṅkhati
analyzed: yaḥ kho sabhiya añña titthiya pubbaḥ imasmin dhamma vinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajje ākaṅkhati
translated: “Sabhiya, anyone who was previously a monastic of another religion and who wishes for the going forth and the full ordination in this Teaching and training,

original: upasampadaṁ, so cattāro māse parivasati; catunnaṁ māsānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū
analyzed: upasampadā saḥ cattāraḥ māse parivasati catunnam māsānam accayena āraddha cittāḥ bhikkhū
translated: must wait four months, and then the monks who are satisfied with him
give him the going forth and the full ordination.

analyzed: api ca mā ittha puggala vematta tā viditā ati
translated: But I know that people are different.”

original: “Sace, bhante, aññatitthiyapubbā imasmiṁ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhantā pabbajjaṁ, ākaṅkhantā🔽upasampadaṁ cattāro māse parivasanti, catunnaṁ māsānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū
analyzed: sace bhante añña titthiya pubbā imasmin dhamma vinaye ākaṅkhantā pabbajje ākaṅkhantā  upasampadam cattāraḥ māse parivasanti catunnam māsānam accayena āraddha cittāḥ bhikkhū
translated: “If, Sir, those who were previously monastics of another religion and who wish for the going forth and the full ordination🔽in this Teaching and training must wait four months, and then the monks who are satisfied with them give them the going forth and the full ordination,

original: pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya, ahaṁ cattāri vassāni parivasissāmi; catunnaṁ
analyzed: pabbājenti upasampādenti bhikkhu bhāvāya aham cattāri vassāni parivasissāmi
translated: then I will wait four years, and then the monks who are satisfied with me

original: vassānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājentu upasampādentu bhikkhubhāvāyā”ti.
analyzed: vassānaṃ accayena āraddha cittāḥ bhikkhū pabbājentu upasampādentu bhikkhu bhāvāya ati
translated: When the rains are over, the monks with purified minds should give the going forth and the full ordination into the monkhood.”

original: Alattha kho sabhiyo paribbājako bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ alattha upasampadaṁ …pe…
analyzed: alattha kho sabhiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ bhagavato santike pabbajjam alattha upasampadam pe
translated: The wanderer Sabhiya received the going forth, the full ordination, and the monkhood in the presence of the Buddha. …

original: aññataro kho panāyasmā sabhiyo arahataṁ ahosīti.🔽Sabhiyasuttaṁ chaṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: aññataraḥ kho pana ayasman sabhiyaḥ arahatam ahosi iti 🔽sabhiya suttam chaṭṭha
translated: And Venerable Sabhiya became another one of the arahants.
